The receiving eNB should try to avoid scheduling cell edge UEs in its cells for the concerned PRBs. The Target Cell ID IE received within the UL High Interference Information IE group in the LOAD INFORMATION message indicates the cell for which the corresponding UL High Interference Indication is meant. The receiving eNB shall consider the value of the UL High Interference Information IE group valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update.

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.14 E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE value correspond to the value of the eNB ID IE contained in the Global eNB ID IE (defined in section 9.2.22) identifying the eNB that controls the cell.

9.2.18 UL High Interference Indication - Section Description: This IE provides, per PRB, a 2 level report on interference sensitivity. The interaction between the indication of UL Overload and UL High Interference is implementation specific. 9.2.18 HII IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a PRB (first bit=PRB 0 and so on), for which value ‘"1" indicates ‘high interference sensitivity’ and value "0" indicates ’low interference sensitivity’. The maximum number of Physical Resource Blocks is 110. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the UL High Interference Indication IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB, the occurrence of high interference sensitivity, as seen from the sending eNB. The receiving eNB should try to avoid scheduling cell edge UEs in its cells for the concerned PRBs. The Target Cell ID IE received within the UL High Interference Information IE group in the LOAD INFORMATION message indicates the cell for which the corresponding UL High Interference Indication is meant. The receiving eNB shall consider the value of the UL High Interference Information IE group valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update.

9.2.19 Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) - Section Description: This IE provides an indication on DL power restriction per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP) in a cell and other information needed by a neighbour eNB for interference aware scheduling.

9.2.19 RNTP Per PRB IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a nPRB value (i.e. first bit=PRB 0 and so on), for which the bit value represents RNTP (nPRB), defined in TS 36.213 [11]. Value 0 indicates "Tx not exceeding RNTP threshold". Value 1 indicates "no promise on the Tx power is given". The IE is ignored if the Enhanced RNTP IE is included.

9.2.19 RNTP Threshold IE Semantics: RNTPthreshold is defined in TS 36.213 [11]. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP), whether downlink transmission power is lower than the value indicated by the RNTP Threshold IE. If the Enhanced RNTP IE is included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE, it additionally indicates whether the downlink transmission power is lower than the value specified by the RNTP High Power Threshold IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Enhanced RNTP IE included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is present, the receiving eNB shall consider the received Enhanced RNTP IE value valid starting from the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present.
9.2.19 Number Of Cell-specific Antenna Ports IE Semantics: P (number of antenna ports for cell-specific reference signals) defined in TS 36.211 [10]
9.2.19 P_B IE Semantics: PB is defined in TS 36.213 [11].
9.2.19 PDCCH Interference Impact IE Semantics: Measured by Predicted Number Of Occupied PDCCH OFDM Symbols (see TS 36.211 [10]). Value 0 means "no prediction is available".

8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP), whether downlink transmission power is lower than the value indicated by the RNTP Threshold IE. If the Enhanced RNTP IE is included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE, it additionally indicates whether the downlink transmission power is lower than the value specified by the RNTP High Power Threshold IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Enhanced RNTP IE included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is present, the receiving eNB shall consider the received Enhanced RNTP IE value valid starting from the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present.

9.2.19 Enhanced RNTP Bitmap IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a PRB in a subframe; value "00" indicates "Tx not exceeding RNTP Threshold", value "01" indicates "Tx not exceeding RNTP High Power Threshold", value "11" indicates that "no promise on the Tx power is given". Value "10" is ignored by the receiver". Each position is applicable only in positions corresponding to DL subframes. The first 2 bits correspond to PRB 0 of the first subframe for which the IE is valid, the following 2 bits correspond to PRB 1 of the first subframe for which the IE is valid, and so on. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes (maximum 40). The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of .  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The Enhanced RNTP pattern is continuously repeated.

9.2.19 RNTP High Power Threshold IE Semantics: Defined as the RNTPthreshold in TS 36.213 [11]. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP), whether downlink transmission power is lower than the value indicated by the RNTP Threshold IE. If the Enhanced RNTP IE is included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE, it additionally indicates whether the downlink transmission power is lower than the value specified by the RNTP High Power Threshold IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Enhanced RNTP IE included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is present, the receiving eNB shall consider the received Enhanced RNTP IE value valid starting from the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present.

9.2.19 Start SFN IE Semantics: SFN of the radio frame containing the first subframe when the Enhanced RNTP IE is valid. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP), whether downlink transmission power is lower than the value indicated by the RNTP Threshold IE. If the Enhanced RNTP IE is included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE, it additionally indicates whether the downlink transmission power is lower than the value specified by the RNTP High Power Threshold IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Enhanced RNTP IE included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is present, the receiving eNB shall consider the received Enhanced RNTP IE value valid starting from the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the CoMP Information IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the receiving eNB may take the IE into account for RRM. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid starting in the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE are not present, then the receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE as immediately valid. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid until an update of the same IE, received in a new LOAD INFORMATION message, is considered valid.

9.2.19 Start Subframe Number IE Semantics: Subframe number, within the radio frame indicated by the Start SFN IE, of the first subframe when the Enhanced RNTP IE is valid. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP), whether downlink transmission power is lower than the value indicated by the RNTP Threshold IE. If the Enhanced RNTP IE is included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE, it additionally indicates whether the downlink transmission power is lower than the value specified by the RNTP High Power Threshold IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Enhanced RNTP IE included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is present, the receiving eNB shall consider the received Enhanced RNTP IE value valid starting from the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the CoMP Information IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the receiving eNB may take the IE into account for RRM. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid starting in the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE are not present, then the receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE as immediately valid. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid until an update of the same IE, received in a new LOAD INFORMATION message, is considered valid.

9.2.54 ABS Information - Section Description: This IE provides information about which sub frames the sending eNB is configuring as almost blank subframes and which subset of almost blank subframes are recommended for configuring measurements towards the UE. Almost blank subframes are subframes with reduced power on some physical channels and/or reduced activity. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the ABS Information IE is included in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the ABS Pattern Info IE indicates the subframes designated as almost blank subframes by the sending eNB for the purpose of interference coordination. The receiving eNB may take such information into consideration when scheduling UEs. The receiving eNB shall consider the received information as immediately applicable. The receiving eNB shall consider the value of the ABS Information IE valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "ABS Information", it indicates the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to initiate the Load Indication procedure, with the LOAD INFORMATION message containing the ABS Information IE indicating non-zero ABS patterns in the relevant cells. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "Start NAICS Information", it indicates the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to initiate the Load Indication procedure with the LOAD INFORMATION message containing the Dynamic DL transmission information IE. The first time the Dynamic DL transmission information IE is signalled after receiving the Invoke Indication IE set to "Start NAICS Information", all the NAICS parameters in the NAICS Information IE shall be included. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "Stop NAICS Information", it indicates the sending eNB does not need NAICS information and therefore the receiving eNB should stop signalling NAICS parameters for the concerned cell.

9.2.54 ABS Pattern Info IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a DL subframe, for which value "1" indicates ‘ABS’ and value "0" indicates ’non ABS’. The first position of the ABS pattern corresponds to subframe 0 in a radio frame where SFN = 0. The ABS pattern is continuously repeated in all radio frames. The maximum number of subframes is 40. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the ABS Information IE is included in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the ABS Pattern Info IE indicates the subframes designated as almost blank subframes by the sending eNB for the purpose of interference coordination. The receiving eNB may take such information into consideration when scheduling UEs.
9.2.54 Number Of Cell-specific Antenna Ports IE Semantics: P (number of antenna ports for cell-specific reference signals) defined in TS 36.211 [10]

9.2.54 Measurement Subset IE Semantics: Indicates a subset of the ABS Pattern Info above, and is used to configure specific measurements towards the UE. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation The receiving eNB may use the Measurement Subset IE received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, for the configuration of specific measurements towards the UE.

9.2.54 ABS Pattern Info IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a subframe. Value "1" indicates ‘ABS’ and value "0" indicates ’non ABS’ which is applicable only in positions corresponding to the DL direction. The maximum number of subframes depends on UL/DL subframe configuration. The maximum number of subframes is 20 for UL/DL subframe configuration 1~5; 60 for UL/DL subframe configuration 6; 70 for UL/DL subframe configuration 0. UL/DL subframe configuration defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The first position of the ABS pattern corresponds to subframe 0 in a radio frame where SFN = 0. The ABS pattern is continuously repeated in all radio frames, and restarted each time SFN = 0. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the ABS Information IE is included in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the ABS Pattern Info IE indicates the subframes designated as almost blank subframes by the sending eNB for the purpose of interference coordination. The receiving eNB may take such information into consideration when scheduling UEs.
9.2.54 Number Of Cell-specific Antenna Ports IE Semantics: P (number of antenna ports for cell-specific reference signals) defined in TS 36.211 [10]

9.2.54 Measurement Subset IE Semantics: Indicates a subset of the ABS Pattern Info above, and is used to configure specific measurements towards the UE 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation The receiving eNB may use the Measurement Subset IE received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, for the configuration of specific measurements towards the UE.
9.2.54 ABS Inactive IE Semantics: Indicates that interference coordination by means of almost blank sub frames is not active
ENUMERATED (ABS Information, …, Start NAICS Information, Stop NAICS Information)

9.2.55 Invoke Indication - Section Description: This IE provides an indication about which type of information the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to send back. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Invoke Indication IE is included in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates which type of information the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to send back. The receiving eNB may take such request into account. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "ABS Information", it indicates the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to initiate the Load Indication procedure, with the LOAD INFORMATION message containing the ABS Information IE indicating non-zero ABS patterns in the relevant cells. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "Start NAICS Information", it indicates the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to initiate the Load Indication procedure with the LOAD INFORMATION message containing the Dynamic DL transmission information IE. The first time the Dynamic DL transmission information IE is signalled after receiving the Invoke Indication IE set to "Start NAICS Information", all the NAICS parameters in the NAICS Information IE shall be included. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "Stop NAICS Information", it indicates the sending eNB does not need NAICS information and therefore the receiving eNB should stop signalling NAICS parameters for the concerned cell.
ENUMERATED (sa0, sa1, sa2, sa3, sa4, sa5, sa6, …)

9.1.2.1 Intended UL-DL Configuration IE Semantics: One of the UL-DL configurations defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The UL subframe(s) in the indicated configuration is subset of those in SIB1 UL-DL configuration. This IE applies to TDD only. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Intended UL-DL Configuration IE is included in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates the UL-DL configuration intended to be used by the indicated cell. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Intended UL-DL Configuration IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE.

9.1.2.1 Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE Semantics: This IE applies to TDD only. 9.2.67 Extended UL Interference Overload Info - Section Description: This IE provides report on interference overload for the set of subframes that are subject to UL-DL subframe reconfiguration. This IE applies to TDD only. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the UL Interference Overload Indication IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell on all resource blocks, per PRB. If the Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the UL Interference Overload Indication IE indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell ignoring the UL subframe(s) represented as value "1" in the Associated Subframes IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received UL Interference Overload Indication IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE. If the Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the Extended UL Interference Overload Indication IE indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell on all resource blocks, per PRB, in the UL subframe(s) which is represented as value "1" in the Associated Subframes IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE.

9.2.67 Associated Subframes IE Semantics: The set of subframe(s) to which the Extended UL interference overload indication is applicable. The bitmap from the least significant bit position to the most significant bit position represents subframes #{3, 4, 7, 8, 9} in a radio frame. Value "1" in a bit position indicates that the Extended UL interference overload indication is applicable to the corresponding subframe; and value "0" indicates otherwise. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the UL Interference Overload Indication IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell on all resource blocks, per PRB. If the Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the UL Interference Overload Indication IE indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell ignoring the UL subframe(s) represented as value "1" in the Associated Subframes IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received UL Interference Overload Indication IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE. If the Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the Extended UL Interference Overload Indication IE indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell on all resource blocks, per PRB, in the UL subframe(s) which is represented as value "1" in the Associated Subframes IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE.

9.2.17 UL Interference Overload Indication - Section Description: This IE provides, per PRB, a report on interference overload. The interaction between the indication of UL Interference Overload and UL High Interference is implementation specific. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the Extended UL Interference Overload Indication IE indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell on all resource blocks, per PRB, in the UL subframe(s) which is represented as value "1" in the Associated Subframes IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE.
ENUMERATED (high interference, medium interference, low interference, …)

9.2.17 UL Interference Overload Indication IE Semantics: Each PRB is identified by its position in the list: the first element in the list corresponds to PRB 0, the second to PRB 1, etc. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the UL Interference Overload Indication IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell on all resource blocks, per PRB. If the Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the UL Interference Overload Indication IE indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell ignoring the UL subframe(s) represented as value "1" in the Associated Subframes IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received UL Interference Overload Indication IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE. If the Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the Extended UL Interference Overload Indication IE indicates the interference level experienced by the indicated cell on all resource blocks, per PRB, in the UL subframe(s) which is represented as value "1" in the Associated Subframes IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Extended UL Interference Overload Info IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update of the same IE.

9.2.74 CoMP Information - Section Description: This IE provides the list of CoMP hypothesis sets, where each CoMP hypothesis set is the collection of CoMP hypothesis(es) of one or multiple cells and each CoMP hypothesis set is associated with a benefit metric. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the CoMP Information IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the receiving eNB may take the IE into account for RRM. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid starting in the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE are not present, then the receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE as immediately valid. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid until an update of the same IE, received in a new LOAD INFORMATION message, is considered valid.
9.2.75 CoMP Hypothesis Set - Section Description: This IE provides a set of CoMP hypotheses. A CoMP hypothesis is hypothetical PRB-specific resource allocation information for a cell.

9.2.75 Cell ID IE Semantics: ID of the cell for which the CoMP Hypothesis IE is applied. 9.2.14 ECGI - Section Description: The E-UTRAN Cell Global Identifier (ECGI) is used to globally identify a cell (see TS 36.401 [2]). 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the UL High Interference Indication IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB, the occurrence of high interference sensitivity, as seen from the sending eNB. The receiving eNB should try to avoid scheduling cell edge UEs in its cells for the concerned PRBs. The Target Cell ID IE received within the UL High Interference Information IE group in the LOAD INFORMATION message indicates the cell for which the corresponding UL High Interference Indication is meant. The receiving eNB shall consider the value of the UL High Interference Information IE group valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update.

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.14 E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE value correspond to the value of the eNB ID IE contained in the Global eNB ID IE (defined in section 9.2.22) identifying the eNB that controls the cell.

9.2.75 CoMP Hypothesis IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a PRB in a subframe, for which value "1" indicates ‘interference protected resource’ and value "0" indicates ‘resource with no utilization constraints,’ which is applicable only in positions corresponding to the DL direction. The first bit corresponds to PRB 0 of the first subframe for which the IE is valid, the second bit corresponds to PRB 1 of the first subframe for which the IE is valid, and so on. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes. The length of the bit string is an integer (maximum 40) multiple of .  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The CoMP hypothesis pattern is continuously repeated.

9.2.74 Benefit Metric IE Semantics: Value -100 indicates the maximum cost, and 100 indicates the maximum benefit. Value -101 indicates unknown benefit. Values from -100 to 100 should be calculated on a linear scale.

9.2.74 Start SFN IE Semantics: SFN of the radio frame containing the first subframe when the CoMP Information IE is valid. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP), whether downlink transmission power is lower than the value indicated by the RNTP Threshold IE. If the Enhanced RNTP IE is included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE, it additionally indicates whether the downlink transmission power is lower than the value specified by the RNTP High Power Threshold IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Enhanced RNTP IE included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is present, the receiving eNB shall consider the received Enhanced RNTP IE value valid starting from the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the CoMP Information IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the receiving eNB may take the IE into account for RRM. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid starting in the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE are not present, then the receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE as immediately valid. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid until an update of the same IE, received in a new LOAD INFORMATION message, is considered valid.

9.2.74 Start Subframe Number IE Semantics: Subframe number, within the radio frame indicated by the Start SFN IE, of the first subframe when the CoMP Information IE is valid. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, it indicates, per PRB or per subframe per PRB (Enhanced RNTP), whether downlink transmission power is lower than the value indicated by the RNTP Threshold IE. If the Enhanced RNTP IE is included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE, it additionally indicates whether the downlink transmission power is lower than the value specified by the RNTP High Power Threshold IE. The receiving eNB may take such information into account when setting its scheduling policy and shall consider the received Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE value valid until reception of a new LOAD INFORMATION message carrying an update. If the Enhanced RNTP IE included in the Relative Narrowband Tx Power (RNTP) IE is present, the receiving eNB shall consider the received Enhanced RNTP IE value valid starting from the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the CoMP Information IE is received in the LOAD INFORMATION message, the receiving eNB may take the IE into account for RRM. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid starting in the subframe indicated by the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE, if present. If the Start SFN IE and Start Subframe Number IE are not present, then the receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE as immediately valid. The receiving eNB shall consider the CoMP Information IE valid until an update of the same IE, received in a new LOAD INFORMATION message, is considered valid.

9.2.77 Dynamic DL transmission information - Section Description: This IE contains assistance information for DL interference mitigation. 8.3.1 Load Indication 8.3.1.2 Successful Operation If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "ABS Information", it indicates the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to initiate the Load Indication procedure, with the LOAD INFORMATION message containing the ABS Information IE indicating non-zero ABS patterns in the relevant cells. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "Start NAICS Information", it indicates the sending eNB would like the receiving eNB to initiate the Load Indication procedure with the LOAD INFORMATION message containing the Dynamic DL transmission information IE. The first time the Dynamic DL transmission information IE is signalled after receiving the Invoke Indication IE set to "Start NAICS Information", all the NAICS parameters in the NAICS Information IE shall be included. If the Invoke Indication IE is set to "Stop NAICS Information", it indicates the sending eNB does not need NAICS information and therefore the receiving eNB should stop signalling NAICS parameters for the concerned cell.

9.2.77 Transmission Modes IE Semantics: The set bits indicate some or all transmission modes: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, as defined in TS 36.213 [23, 7.1]. The first/ leftmost bit is for transmission mode 1, the second bit is for transmission mode 2, and so on.
9.2.77 P_B IE Semantics: See TS 36.213 [23, Table 5.2-1]
ENUMERATED (dB-6, dB-4dot77, dB-3, dB-1dot77, dB0, dB1, dB2, dB3, ...)
9.2.77 P_A IE Semantics: See PA TS 36.213 [23, 5.2]. Value dB-6 corresponds to -6 dB, dB-4dot77 corresponds to -4.77 dB etc.

section_list.name: ERROR INDICATION
aoa:
This message is used to indicate that some error has been detected in the eNB/en-gNB.
Direction: eNB1 ? eNB2 or eNB ? en-gNB or en-gNB ? eNB.
9.2.13 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)

9.1.2.2 Old eNB UE X2AP ID IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the source eNB and for dual connectivity at the SeNB or the eNB from which the E-RAB context is transferred. 9.2.24 eNB UE X2AP ID - Section Description: This information element, combined with the eNB UE X2AP ID Extension when present regardless its value, uniquely identifies an UE over the X2 interface within an eNB. The usage of this IE is defined in TS 36.401 [2]. NOTE: If X2-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the eNB UE X2AP ID, combined with the eNB UE X2AP ID Extension, if applicable, is allocated so that it can be associated with an X2-C interface instance. 8.3.2 Error Indication 8.3.2.2 Successful Operation In case the Error Indication procedure is triggered by UE associated signalling, in the course of handover signalling and signalling for dual connectivity, the Old eNB UE X2AP ID IE and the New eNB UE X2AP ID IE shall be included in the ERROR INDICATION message. In case the Error Indication procedure is triggered by UE associated signalling, in the course of signalling for EN-DC, the Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID IE and the New eNB UE X2AP ID IE shall be included in the ERROR INDICATION message. If any of Old eNB UE X2AP ID IE, Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID IE and New eNB UE X2AP ID IE is not correct, the cause shall be set to appropriate value e.g. "unknown Old eNB UE X2AP ID", "unknown Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID", "unknown New eNB UE X2AP ID" or "unknown pair of UE X2AP ID".

9.1.2.2 New eNB UE X2AP ID IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the target eNB and for dual connectivity/EN-DC at the MeNB or the eNB to which the E-RAB context is transferred. 9.2.24 eNB UE X2AP ID - Section Description: This information element, combined with the eNB UE X2AP ID Extension when present regardless its value, uniquely identifies an UE over the X2 interface within an eNB. The usage of this IE is defined in TS 36.401 [2]. NOTE: If X2-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the eNB UE X2AP ID, combined with the eNB UE X2AP ID Extension, if applicable, is allocated so that it can be associated with an X2-C interface instance. 8.3.2 Error Indication 8.3.2.2 Successful Operation In case the Error Indication procedure is triggered by UE associated signalling, in the course of handover signalling and signalling for dual connectivity, the Old eNB UE X2AP ID IE and the New eNB UE X2AP ID IE shall be included in the ERROR INDICATION message. In case the Error Indication procedure is triggered by UE associated signalling, in the course of signalling for EN-DC, the Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID IE and the New eNB UE X2AP ID IE shall be included in the ERROR INDICATION message. If any of Old eNB UE X2AP ID IE, Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID IE and New eNB UE X2AP ID IE is not correct, the cause shall be set to appropriate value e.g. "unknown Old eNB UE X2AP ID", "unknown Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID", "unknown New eNB UE X2AP ID" or "unknown pair of UE X2AP ID".

9.2.6 Cause - Section Description: The purpose of the cause information element is to indicate the reason for a particular event for the whole protocol. 8.3.2 Error Indication 8.3.2.2 Successful Operation The ERROR INDICATION message shall contain at least either the Cause IE or the Criticality Diagnostics IE.

ENUMERATED (Handover Desirable for Radio Reasons, Time Critical Handover, Resource Optimisation Handover, Reduce Load in Serving Cell, Partial Handover, Unknown New eNB UE X2AP ID, Unknown Old eNB UE X2AP ID, Unknown Pair of UE X2AP ID, HO Target not Allowed, TX2RELOCoverall Expiry, TRELOCprep Expiry, Cell not Available, No Radio Resources Available in Target Cell, Invalid MME Group ID, Unknown MME Code, Encryption And/Or Integrity Protection Algorithms Not Supported, ReportCharacteristicsEmpty, NoReportPeriodicity, ExistingMeasurementID, Unknown eNB Measurement ID, Measurement Temporarily not Available, Unspecified, ..., Load Balancing, Handover Optimisation, Value out of allowed range, Multiple E-RAB ID instances, Switch Off Ongoing, Not supported QCI value, Measurement not supported for the object, TDCoverall Expiry, TDCprep Expiry, Action Desirable for Radio Reasons, Reduce Load, Resource Optimisation, Time Critical action, Target not Allowed, No Radio Resources Available, Invalid QoS combination, Encryption Algorithms Not Supported, Procedure cancelled, RRM purpose, Improve user bit rate, User Inactivity, Radio Connection With UE Lost, Failure in the Radio Interface Procedure, Bearer Option not Supported, MCG Mobility, SCG Mobility, Count reaches max value, Unknown Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID, PDCP Overload)

ENUMERATED (Transfer Syntax Error, Abstract Syntax Error (Reject), Abstract Syntax Error (Ignore and Notify), Message not Compatible with Receiver State, Semantic Error, Unspecified, Abstract Syntax Error (Falsely Constructed Message), ...)
ENUMERATED (Control Processing Overload, Hardware Failure, O&M Intervention, Not enough User Plane Processing Resources, Unspecified, ...)

9.2.7 Criticality Diagnostics - Section Description: The Criticality Diagnostics IE is sent by the eNB/en-gNB when parts of a received message have not been comprehended or were missing, or if the message contained logical errors. When applicable, it contains information about which IEs were not comprehended or were missing. 8.3.2 Error Indication 8.3.2.2 Successful Operation The ERROR INDICATION message shall contain at least either the Cause IE or the Criticality Diagnostics IE.

9.2.7 Procedure Code IE Semantics: Procedure Code is to be used if Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure, and not within the response message of the same procedure that caused the error.
ENUMERATED (initiating message, successful outcome, unsuccessful outcome)
9.2.7 Triggering Message IE Semantics: The Triggering Message is used only if the Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure.
9.2.7 Procedure Criticality IE Semantics: This Procedure Criticality is used for reporting the Criticality of the Triggering message (Procedure).
9.2.7 IE Criticality IE Semantics: The IE Criticality is used for reporting the criticality of the triggering IE. The value "ignore'" shall not be used.
9.2.7 IE ID IE Semantics: The IE ID of the not understood or missing IE
9.1.2.2 Old eNB UE X2AP ID Extension IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the source eNB and for dual connectivity at the SeNB or the eNB from which the E-RAB context is transferred.
9.1.2.2 New eNB UE X2AP ID Extension IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the target eNB and for dual connectivity at the MeNB or the eNB to which the E-RAB context is transferred.

9.1.2.2 Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID IE Semantics: Allocated for EN-DC at the en-gNB. 9.2.100 en-gNB UE X2AP ID - Section Description: This information element uniquely identifies an UE over the X2 interface within an en-gNB. The usage of this IE is defined in TS 36.401 [2]. NOTE: If X2-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the en-gNB UE X2AP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with an X2-C interface instance. 8.3.2 Error Indication 8.3.2.2 Successful Operation In case the Error Indication procedure is triggered by UE associated signalling, in the course of handover signalling and signalling for dual connectivity, the Old eNB UE X2AP ID IE and the New eNB UE X2AP ID IE shall be included in the ERROR INDICATION message. In case the Error Indication procedure is triggered by UE associated signalling, in the course of signalling for EN-DC, the Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID IE and the New eNB UE X2AP ID IE shall be included in the ERROR INDICATION message. If any of Old eNB UE X2AP ID IE, Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID IE and New eNB UE X2AP ID IE is not correct, the cause shall be set to appropriate value e.g. "unknown Old eNB UE X2AP ID", "unknown Old en-gNB UE X2AP ID", "unknown New eNB UE X2AP ID" or "unknown pair of UE X2AP ID".

9.2.143 Interface Instance Indication - Section Description: The Interface Instance Indication identifies the interface instance the X2AP message is destined for. NOTE: The Interface Instance Indication is allocated so that it can be associated with an X2-C interface instance. The Interface Instance Indication may identify more than one interface instance. 8.3.2 Error Indication 8.3.2.2 Successful Operation In case of network sharing with multiple cell ID broadcast with shared X2-C signalling transport, as specified in TS 36.300 [15], if the Error Indication procedure is triggered by non UE-associated signalling, the ERROR INDICATION message shall include the Interface Instance Indication IE to identify the corresponding interface instance.

section_list.name: X2 SETUP REQUEST
aoa:
This message is sent by an eNB to a neighbouring eNB to transfer the initialization information for a TNL association.
Direction: eNB1 --> eNB2.
9.2.13 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)
9.2.22 Global eNB ID - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an eNB (see TS 36.401 [2]).

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.22 Macro eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 20 leftmost bits of the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying each cell controlled by the eNB
9.2.22 Home eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying the cell controlled by the eNB

9.2.22 Short Macro eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 18 leftmost bits of the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying each cell controlled by the eNB.

9.2.22 Long Macro eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 21 leftmost bits of the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying each cell controlled by the eNB.
9.1.2.3 Served Cells IE Semantics: Complete list of cells served by the eNB
9.2.8 Served Cell Information - Section Description: This IE contains cell configuration information of a cell that a neighbour eNB may need for the X2 AP interface.
9.2.8 PCI IE Semantics: Physical Cell ID
9.2.14 ECGI - Section Description: The E-UTRAN Cell Global Identifier (ECGI) is used to globally identify a cell (see TS 36.401 [2]).

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.14 E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE value correspond to the value of the eNB ID IE contained in the Global eNB ID IE (defined in section 9.2.22) identifying the eNB that controls the cell.

9.2.8 TAC IE Semantics: Tracking Area Code 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The Neighbour Information IE shall only include E-UTRAN cells that are direct neighbours of cells in the reporting eNB. A direct neighbour of one cell of a given eNB may be any cell belonging to an eNB that is a neighbour of that given eNB cell e.g. even if the cell has not been reported by a UE. The initiating eNB1 may include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].
9.2.8 Broadcast PLMNs IE Semantics: Broadcast PLMNs

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.8 UL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to NUL in TS 36.104 [16] for E-UTRA operating bands for which it is defined; ignored for E-UTRA operating bands for which NUL is not defined 9.2.26 EARFCN - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.26 EARFCN IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].

9.2.8 DL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to NDL in TS 36.104 [16] 9.2.26 EARFCN - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.26 EARFCN IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].
ENUMERATED (bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100, ... , bw1)

9.2.8 UL Transmission Bandwidth IE Semantics: Same as DL Transmission Bandwidth in this release; ignored in case UL EARFCN value is ignored 9.2.27 Transmission Bandwidth - Section Description: The Transmission Bandwidth IE is used to indicate the UL or DL transmission bandwidth expressed in units of resource blocks " NRB " (TS 36.104 [16]). The values bw1, bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100 correspond to the number of resource blocks "NRB" 6, 15, 25, 50, 75, 100.
ENUMERATED (bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100, ... , bw1)

9.2.27 Transmission Bandwidth - Section Description: The Transmission Bandwidth IE is used to indicate the UL or DL transmission bandwidth expressed in units of resource blocks " NRB " (TS 36.104 [16]). The values bw1, bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100 correspond to the number of resource blocks "NRB" 6, 15, 25, 50, 75, 100.

9.2.8 UL EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: If this IE is present, the value signalled in the UL EARFCN IE is ignored. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number Extension defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].

9.2.8 DL EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: If this IE is present, the value signalled in the DL EARFCN IE is ignored. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number Extension defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].
│  │  │  │     ├─Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to DL EARFCN

9.2.8 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to DL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to MDL in TS 36.104 [16] 9.2.94 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to EARFCN - Section Description: This IE is used to indicate the offset of the NB-IoT Channel Number to the EARFCN (TS 36.104 [16]).
│  │  │  │     ├─Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to UL EARFCN

9.2.8 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to UL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to MUL in TS 36.104 [16] 9.2.94 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to EARFCN - Section Description: This IE is used to indicate the offset of the NB-IoT Channel Number to the EARFCN (TS 36.104 [16]).
9.2.8 NRS-NSSS-PowerOffset IE Semantics: NRS to NSSS power ratio, as defined in TS6.213 [11].
9.2.8 NSSS-NumOccasionDifferentPrecoder IE Semantics: The number of consecutive NSSS occasions that use different precoders for NSSS transmission, as defined in TS6.213 [11].

9.2.8 EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to NDL/NUL in TS 36.104 [16] 9.2.26 EARFCN - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.26 EARFCN IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].
ENUMERATED (bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100, ... , bw1)

9.2.27 Transmission Bandwidth - Section Description: The Transmission Bandwidth IE is used to indicate the UL or DL transmission bandwidth expressed in units of resource blocks " NRB " (TS 36.104 [16]). The values bw1, bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100 correspond to the number of resource blocks "NRB" 6, 15, 25, 50, 75, 100.
ENUMERATED (sa0, sa1, sa2, sa3, sa4, sa5, sa6, …)
9.2.8 Subframe Assignment IE Semantics: Uplink-downlink subframe configuration information defined in TS 36.211 [10]. In NB-IOT, sa0 and sa6 are not applicable.
9.2.8 Special Subframe Info IE Semantics: Special subframe configuration information defined in TS 36.211 [10]
ENUMERATED (ssp0, ssp1, ssp2, ssp3, ssp4, ssp5, ssp6, ssp7, ssp8, …)
9.2.8 Additional Special Subframe Info IE Semantics: Special subframe configuration information defined in TS 36.211 [10]. Only for newly defined configuration of special subframe from Release 11.
ENUMERATED (ssp0, ssp1, ssp2, ssp3, ssp4, ssp5, ssp6, ssp7, ssp8, ssp9, …)

9.2.8 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: If this IE is present, the value signalled in the EARFCN IE is ignored. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number Extension defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].

9.2.8 Additional Special Subframe Extension Info IE Semantics: Special subframe configuration information defined in TS 36.211 [10]. Only for newly defined configuration of special subframe from Release 14.
│  │  │        ├─Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to DL EARFCN

9.2.8 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to DL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to MDL in TS 36.104 [16] 9.2.94 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to EARFCN - Section Description: This IE is used to indicate the offset of the NB-IoT Channel Number to the EARFCN (TS 36.104 [16]).

9.2.8 NB-IoT UL DL Alignment Offset IE Semantics: Corresponds to the TDD-UL-DL-AlignmentOffset-NB in TS 36.331 [9]. 9.2.144 NB-IoT UL DL Alignment Offset - Section Description: This IE is used to indicate the offset between the UL carrier frequency center with respect to DL carrier frequency center. 9.2.144 NB-IoT UL DL Alignment Offset IE Semantics: Unit: kHz

9.2.43 Number of Antenna Ports - Section Description: The Number of Antenna Ports IE is used to indicate the number of cell specific antenna ports. 9.2.43 Number of Antenna Ports IE Semantics: an1 = One antenna port an2 = Two antenna ports an4 = Four antenna ports 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the Number of Antenna Ports IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the Number of Antenna Ports IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.331 [9].

9.2.50 PRACH Configuration - Section Description: This IE indicates the PRACH resources used in neighbor cell. 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the PRACH Configuration IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the PRACH Configuration IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use this information for RACH optimisation.
9.2.50 RootSequenceIndex IE Semantics: See section 5.7.2. in TS 36.211 [10]
9.2.50 ZeroCorrelationZoneConfiguration IE Semantics: See section 5.7.2. in TS 36.211 [10]
9.2.50 HighSpeedFlag IE Semantics: TRUE corresponds to Restricted set and FALSE to Unrestricted set. See section 5.7.2 in TS 36.211 [10]
9.2.50 PRACH-FrequencyOffset IE Semantics: See section 5.7.1 of TS 36.211 [10]
9.2.50 PRACH-ConfigurationIndex IE Semantics: Mandatory for TDD, shall not be present for FDD. See section 5.7.1. in TS 36.211 [10]

9.2.8 MBSFN Subframe Info IE Semantics: MBSFN subframe defined in TS 36.331 [9] 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the MBSFN Subframe Info IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the MBSFN Subframe Info IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.331 [9].
ENUMERATED (n1, n2, n4, n8, n16, n32, …)

9.2.51 Subframe Allocation - Section Description: The Subframe Allocation IE is used to indicate the subframes that are allocated for MBSFN within the radio frame allocation period as defined in TS 36.331 [9].

9.2.53 CSG ID - Section Description: This element indicates the identifier of the Closed Subscriber Group. 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation For each CSG cell or hybrid cell served by the initiating eNB1 the X2 SETUP REQUEST message shall contain the CSG ID IE. For each CSG cell or hybrid cell served by the candidate eNB2 the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message shall contain the CSG ID IE. The eNB receiving the IE shall take this information into account when further deciding whether X2 handover between the source cell and the target cell may be performed.

9.2.8 MBMS Service Area Identity List IE Semantics: Supported MBMS Service Area Identities in the cell 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the MBMS Service Area Identity List IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the MBMS Service Area Identity List IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].
9.2.8 MBMS Service Area Identity IE Semantics: MBMS Service Area Identities as defined in TS 23.003 [29]

9.2.60 MultibandInfoList - Section Description: The MultibandInfoList IE contains the additional frequency band indicators that a cell belongs to listed in decreasing order of preference, see TS 36.331 [9]. 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation For each cell served by the initiating eNB1 the X2 SETUP REQUEST message may contain the MultibandInfoList IE and may also contain the FreqBandIndicatorPriority IE. For each cell served by the candidate eNB2 the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message may contain the MultibandInfoList IE and may also contain the FreqBandIndicatorPriority IE. The eNB receiving the MultibandInfoList IE shall, if supported, take this information into account when further deciding whether subsequent mobility actions between the source cell and the target cell may be performed, and use this IE and the FreqBandIndicatorPriority IE, if received, as specified in TS 36.331 [9].
9.2.60 FrequencyBandIndicator IE Semantics: E-UTRA operating band as defined in TS 36.101 [42, table 5.5-1]

9.2.8 FreqBandIndicatorPriority IE Semantics: This IE indicates that the eNodeB supports FreqBandIndicationPriority, and whether FreqBandIndicatorPriority is broadcasted in SIB 1 (see TS 36.331 [9]) 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation For each cell served by the initiating eNB1 the X2 SETUP REQUEST message may contain the MultibandInfoList IE and may also contain the FreqBandIndicatorPriority IE. For each cell served by the candidate eNB2 the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message may contain the MultibandInfoList IE and may also contain the FreqBandIndicatorPriority IE. The eNB receiving the MultibandInfoList IE shall, if supported, take this information into account when further deciding whether subsequent mobility actions between the source cell and the target cell may be performed, and use this IE and the FreqBandIndicatorPriority IE, if received, as specified in TS 36.331 [9].

9.2.8 BandwidthReducedSI IE Semantics: This IE indicates that the SystemInformationBlockType1-BR is scheduled in the cell (see TS 36.331 [9]) 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the BandwidthReducedSI IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include BandwidthReducedSI IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it to determine a suitable target in case of subsequent outgoing mobility involving BL UEs or UEs requiring CE.

9.2.8 Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication IE Semantics: This IE indicates which E-UTRA control/reference signal resources are protected and are not subject to E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination. 9.2.125 Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication - Section Description: This IE indicates the resources allocated for E-UTRA DL and UL reference and control signals (hereby referred to as protected resources). This information is used in the process of E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination. 8.7.1 EN-DC X2 Setup 8.7.1.2 Successful Operation If the EN-DC X2 SETUP REQUEST message contains the Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication IE, the receiving en-gNB should take this into account for cell-level resource coordination with the eNB. The en-gNB shall consider the received Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication IE content valid until reception of a new update of the IE for the same eNB.
9.2.125 Activation SFN IE Semantics: Indicates from which SFN of the receiving node the resource allocation is valid.

9.2.125 Protected Resource List IE Semantics: The protected resource pattern is continuously repeated, and it is valid until stated otherwise or until replaced by a new pattern. The pattern does not apply in reserved subframes.
9.2.125 Protected Resource List Item IE Semantics: Each item describes one transmission pattern. A pattern may comprise several control signals.
9.2.125 Resource Type IE Semantics: Indicates whether the protected resource is E-UTRA DL non-CRS, E-UTRA CRS or E-UTRA UL.

9.2.125 Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint IE Semantics: The bitmap of REs occupied by the protected signal within one PRB. Each position in the bitmap represents an RE in one PRB; value “0” indicates "resource not protected", value “1” indicates "resource protected ". The first bit of the string corresponds to the RE with the smallest time and frequency index in the PRB, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The length of the bit string equals the product of  and the length of PRB in time dimension, measured in REs.  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The intra-PRB pattern consisting of all "1"s is equivalent to PRB-level granularity.

9.2.125 Protected Footprint Frequency Pattern IE Semantics: The bit string indicates in which PRBs inside carrier bandwidth the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint applies. How often in time dimension this frequency pattern applies, depends on time periodicity of Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint. The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier bandwidth, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. Each position in the string represents a PRB; value "0" indicates " Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint does not appear in PRB", value "1" indicates "Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears in PRB". The length of the bit string equals the number of PRBs in the carrier bandwidth.
9.2.125 Protected Footprint Time Pattern IE Semantics: The description of time periodicity of the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint.

9.2.125 Protected Footprint Time-periodicity IE Semantics: Periodicity with which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint repeats in time-dimension (1= every PRB (i.e. slot), 2=every other PRB (i.e. slot) etc.

9.2.125 Protected Footprint Start Time IE Semantics: The time-position of the PRB inside the frame in which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears for the first time. The value "1" corresponds to the receiving node’s slot 0 in subframe 0 in the receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN.
9.2.125 MBSFN Control Region Length IE Semantics: Length of control region in MBSFN subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.
9.2.125 PDCCH Region Length IE Semantics: Length of PDCCH region in regular subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.

9.2.8 Broadcast PLMN Identity Info List E-UTRA IE Semantics: This IE corresponds to the cellAccessRelatedInfo IE in SIB1 as specified in TS 36.331 [9]. The PLMN Identities and associated information contained in this IE shall be provided in the same order as broadcast in SIB1.

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The Neighbour Information IE shall only include E-UTRAN cells that are direct neighbours of cells in the reporting eNB. A direct neighbour of one cell of a given eNB may be any cell belonging to an eNB that is a neighbour of that given eNB cell e.g. even if the cell has not been reported by a UE. The initiating eNB1 may include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].

8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The Neighbour Information IE shall only include E-UTRAN cells that are direct neighbours of cells in the reporting eNB. A direct neighbour of one cell of a given eNB may be any cell belonging to an eNB that is a neighbour of that given eNB cell e.g. even if the cell has not been reported by a UE. The initiating eNB1 may include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15]. The initiating eNB1 may include the NR Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the NR Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The NR Neighbour Information IE shall only include NR cells capable of performing EN-DC with the corresponding served E-UTRA cell. The eNB receiving the NR Neighbour Information IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].

9.1.2.3 ECGI IE Semantics: E-UTRAN Cell Global Identifier of the neighbour cell 9.2.14 ECGI - Section Description: The E-UTRAN Cell Global Identifier (ECGI) is used to globally identify a cell (see TS 36.401 [2]).

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.14 E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE value correspond to the value of the eNB ID IE contained in the Global eNB ID IE (defined in section 9.2.22) identifying the eNB that controls the cell.
9.1.2.3 PCI IE Semantics: Physical Cell Identifier of the neighbour cell

9.1.2.3 EARFCN IE Semantics: DL EARFCN for FDD or EARFCN for TDD 9.2.26 EARFCN - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.26 EARFCN IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].

9.1.2.3 TAC IE Semantics: Tracking Area Code 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The Neighbour Information IE shall only include E-UTRAN cells that are direct neighbours of cells in the reporting eNB. A direct neighbour of one cell of a given eNB may be any cell belonging to an eNB that is a neighbour of that given eNB cell e.g. even if the cell has not been reported by a UE. The initiating eNB1 may include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].

9.1.2.3 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: DL EARFCN for FDD or EARFCN for TDD. If this IE is present, the value signalled in the EARFCN IE is ignored. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number Extension defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].

9.1.2.3 NR Neighbour Information IE Semantics: NR neighbour, capable of performing EN-DC with the served E-UTRA cell 9.2.98 NR Neighbour Information - Section Description: This IE contains cell configuration information of NR cells that a neighbour node may need for the X2 AP interface. 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the NR Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the NR Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The NR Neighbour Information IE shall only include NR cells capable of performing EN-DC with the corresponding served E-UTRA cell. The eNB receiving the NR Neighbour Information IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].

8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the NR Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the NR Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The NR Neighbour Information IE shall only include NR cells capable of performing EN-DC with the corresponding served E-UTRA cell. The eNB receiving the NR Neighbour Information IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].
9.2.98 NRPCI IE Semantics: NR Physical Cell ID
9.2.111 NR CGI - Section Description: The NR Cell Global Identifier (NR CGI) is used to globally identify an NR cell (see TS 38.401 [34]).

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.111 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE value correspond to the value of the en-gNB ID IE contained in the Global en-gNB ID IE (defined in section 9.2.112) identifying the en-gNB that controls the cell.
9.2.98 5GS-TAC IE Semantics: Broadcast 5GS Tracking Area Code

9.2.98 Configured TAC IE Semantics: This is the TAC configured in the en-gNB, different from the 5GS TAC broadcast in the NR cell and enables application of Roaming and Access Restrictions for EN-DC as specified in TS 37.340 [32].
9.2.98 Measurement Timing Configuration IE Semantics: Contains the MeasurementTimingConfiguration inter-node message for the neighbour cell, as defined in TS 38.331 [31].
9.1.2.3 GU Group Id List IE Semantics: List of all the pools to which the eNB belongs
9.2.20 GU Group Id - Section Description: The GU Group Id IE is the globally unique group id corresponding to a pool area.

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.83 LHN ID - Section Description: The LHN ID IE is used to indicate the LHN ID of the eNB, as defined in TS 23.003 [21]. 9.2.83 Local Home Network ID IE Semantics: Identifies the Local Home Network. 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the LHN ID IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include LHN ID IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].

section_list.name: X2 SETUP RESPONSE
aoa:
This message is sent by an eNB to a neighbouring eNB to transfer the initialization information for a TNL association.
Direction: eNB2 ? eNB1.
9.2.13 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)
9.2.22 Global eNB ID - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an eNB (see TS 36.401 [2]).

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.22 Macro eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 20 leftmost bits of the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying each cell controlled by the eNB
9.2.22 Home eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying the cell controlled by the eNB

9.2.22 Short Macro eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 18 leftmost bits of the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying each cell controlled by the eNB.

9.2.22 Long Macro eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 21 leftmost bits of the value of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE contained in the ECGI IE (see section 9.2.14) identifying each cell controlled by the eNB.
9.1.2.4 Served Cells IE Semantics: Complete list of cells served by the eNB
9.2.8 Served Cell Information - Section Description: This IE contains cell configuration information of a cell that a neighbour eNB may need for the X2 AP interface.
9.2.8 PCI IE Semantics: Physical Cell ID
9.2.14 ECGI - Section Description: The E-UTRAN Cell Global Identifier (ECGI) is used to globally identify a cell (see TS 36.401 [2]).

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.14 E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRAN Cell Identifier IE value correspond to the value of the eNB ID IE contained in the Global eNB ID IE (defined in section 9.2.22) identifying the eNB that controls the cell.

9.2.8 TAC IE Semantics: Tracking Area Code 8.3.3 X2 Setup 8.3.3.2 Successful Operation The initiating eNB1 may include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The Neighbour Information IE shall only include E-UTRAN cells that are direct neighbours of cells in the reporting eNB. A direct neighbour of one cell of a given eNB may be any cell belonging to an eNB that is a neighbour of that given eNB cell e.g. even if the cell has not been reported by a UE. The initiating eNB1 may include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP REQUEST message. The candidate eNB2 may also include the TAC IE with the Neighbour Information IE in the X2 SETUP RESPONSE message. The eNB receiving the IE may use it according to TS 36.300 [15].
9.2.8 Broadcast PLMNs IE Semantics: Broadcast PLMNs

9.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This information element indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: - digits 0 to 9, encoded 0000 to 1001, - 1111 used as filler digit, two digits per octet, - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n -The PLMN identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either -a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or -3 digits from MNC (in case of a 3 digit MNC).

9.2.8 UL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to NUL in TS 36.104 [16] for E-UTRA operating bands for which it is defined; ignored for E-UTRA operating bands for which NUL is not defined 9.2.26 EARFCN - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.26 EARFCN IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].

9.2.8 DL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to NDL in TS 36.104 [16] 9.2.26 EARFCN - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.26 EARFCN IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].
ENUMERATED (bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100, ... , bw1)

9.2.8 UL Transmission Bandwidth IE Semantics: Same as DL Transmission Bandwidth in this release; ignored in case UL EARFCN value is ignored 9.2.27 Transmission Bandwidth - Section Description: The Transmission Bandwidth IE is used to indicate the UL or DL transmission bandwidth expressed in units of resource blocks " NRB " (TS 36.104 [16]). The values bw1, bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100 correspond to the number of resource blocks "NRB" 6, 15, 25, 50, 75, 100.
ENUMERATED (bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100, ... , bw1)

9.2.27 Transmission Bandwidth - Section Description: The Transmission Bandwidth IE is used to indicate the UL or DL transmission bandwidth expressed in units of resource blocks " NRB " (TS 36.104 [16]). The values bw1, bw6, bw15, bw25, bw50, bw75, bw100 correspond to the number of resource blocks "NRB" 6, 15, 25, 50, 75, 100.

9.2.8 UL EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: If this IE is present, the value signalled in the UL EARFCN IE is ignored. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number Extension defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].

9.2.8 DL EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: If this IE is present, the value signalled in the DL EARFCN IE is ignored. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number Extension defines the carrier frequency used in a cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.65 EARFCN Extension IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [16].
│  │  │  │     ├─Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to DL EARFCN

9.2.8 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to DL EARFCN IE Semantics: Corresponds to MDL in TS 36.104 [16] 9.2.94 Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to EARFCN - Section Description: This IE is used to indicate the offset of the NB-IoT Channel Number to the EARFCN (TS 36.104 [16]).
│  │  │  │     ├─Offset of NB-IoT Channel Number to UL EARFCN
